Integers expressible as sums of two dth powers

Dec 18, 2019

Wow, I’ve been bad about updating this. My last post was at the beginning of the semester, and now I’m writing this post at the end of the semester. I applied to grad schools this past week, so maybe that explains the silence (but I think I’ve just been distracted). I took a class called 18.821 this semester: it’s called project lab, and it’s supposed to improve communication skills. You’re supposed to work on three projects throughout the semester, and write up a report after three weeks. I’d like to talk about two of my contributions, neither of which are new, but which are nonetheless fun.

In this post, I’ll talk about the following question: can one write down a parametric family of integer solutions to the equation for ? After running some computer searches, we (i.e., my group) were not able to find any integer solutions for , so we will focus on the cases in this post.

As one would expect, the approach to finding integer solutions to the desired equation is via finding rational points on the surface defined by . First, we notice that is birationally equivalent to a pencil of curves of degree if is odd, and of degree if is even, with at least two rational points. Here’s a sketch: define by the equations

Then setting , , and yields an equation of degree if is odd (and degree if is even) in , and . Fixing one of these variables (the variable parametrizing the pencil) produces an affine curve which has at least one rational point. The second rational point is just the point at .

The approach, then, is as follows: any surface of degree intersecting (rational) points which lie on a line must either contain the line or intersect the line in one other (rational) point. In order to obtain a parametrized family of rational points on , it therefore suffices to find (resp. ) rational points on each fiber of which all lie on the same line if is odd (resp. is even).

Let’s work out the case . The surface is birationally equivalent to a pencil of elliptic curves . Using the variables introduced above, one finds that is isomorphic to the surface in defined by the equation

By varying , we obtain the desired pencil of elliptic curves; the fiber has a rational point (or, homogenizing, the point ). This implies that is a pencil of elliptic curves, so the tangent line to on must intersect at another (necessarily rational, by the rational roots theorem) point.

All in all, this is pretty nice: for , we’ve obtained a parametric family of solutions. Something nice happens in characteristic in the function field setting: the surface is unirational over (and in particular, has a rational family of -rational points), as we shall now demonstrate.

The linearity of Frobenius (i.e., the th power map) in characteristic implies that has a rational point if and only if does, so we can and will assume that is relatively prime to . Note that the Jacobian criterion then implies that is smooth. (Note that by Chevalley-Warning, the surface contains at least one -rational point if , and in this case divides .)

An -point of is equivalently a rational map , so one possible approach to finding (both - and -) rational points on is to understand lines on . Indeed, if a surface in has lines, then a generic hyperplane section has rational points.

Here’s an example. The surface is a cubic surface, so the classical result that there are lines on a cubic surface gives at least distinct -rational points on for any finite field of order with . (Over an algebraically closed of characteristic , there are lines.)

There are primitive third roots of unity in . By setting and (with ), we obtain lines on — permuting coordinates gives the desired lines. Explicitly, these lines are given by

for .

A parametrized family of -rational points on is the same data as a rational map . Since is birational to , it suffices to construct a nontrivial rational map . Such a map certainly exists if is unirational (although this is a much stronger condition, since it says that is surjective).

For instance, the cubic surface is smooth (if ), so it is isomorphic to the blowup of at six points. It follows that is rational (i.e., birationally equivalent to ), so there does indeed exist a rational family of -rational points on . In fact, the family of integral points on discussed above provides an example of a parametrized family of -rational points on . Note that we similarly have a parametrized family of -rational points on , and hence defines a rational map .

None of this was special to characteristic . But the following example displays phenomena that are unique to working in characteristic . Consider the degree surface , where is an odd prime. Motivated by the above discussion, we will try to adopt the methods from the first part of this post. Let us use the notation established in the first part; then the equation defining translates to

which, in terms of , and translates to

If , then this becomes

It follows that the function field is contained in . This defines a rational map , which implies that there is a rational family of -rational points on . If divides , then the map given by sending to is a surjective morphism, so also admits a rational family of -rational points in this case. (In fact, this argument proves the stronger claim that is unirational if divides .). We do not know if is rational (i.e., birationally equivalent to ).
